title: Is Pink Floyd's album, The Wall, the best progressive rock concept album ever made or is there another candidate? - Quora

response.answer_text: I think The Wall is when Pink Floyd jumped the shark. Please, no haters, it’s just my opinion and musical taste. Meddle (Echoes)/Dark side, Wish and Animals were so creative and are still my favorites. I bought The Wall when it came out and do like most of the album....however its very depressing and, I dunno...too British. Kind of like British comedy, some like it, others just don’t get it. I’m still a bit traumatized from seeing The Wall movie. I won’t watch it again. Just too disturbing and ruined the album for me with the depressing mental imagery I now have of the music. And if I never have to hear Another Brick in the Wall for the zillionth time on “classic rock” radio I could die happy. Eat you meat, eat your pudding....please. Arguably the worst song on the album. Having said that a couple of suggestions: Jeff Wayne’s War of the Worlds  A double album (back in 1979?) musical version of the well known story. Talent abounds...Richard Burton, our storyteller, Justin Hayward from the Moody Blues, Phil Lynott (Thin Lizzy) and I’m probably leaving out many of the other talented musicians. A real treat if you’re going on a long drive or have about two hours to immerse yourself in the story. Porcupine Tree-Fear of a Blank Planet  The theme is of overmedicated, bored teens living pointless lives, getting stoned, playing video games and contemplating mass violence. Porcupine Tree-Voyage 34  An entire album devoted to an acid trip. Long instrumentals, trippy, psychedelic. Maybe not for everyone. Thanks to all the Quora responders for their suggestions. A whole lot of music to check out, some I never knew existed.

No, not even close. It’s not even in the top three concept albums by Pink Floyd. ‘The Wall’ has some great moments, but it is the moment where Roger Waters got too much control over the group and, as a result, is self-indulgent, bloated, overlong and in thrall to his obsession with World War II. Each of their previous three albums are better, more concise, more focused. Just look at ‘Wish You Were Here’, a concept album about the idea of absence, as Storm Thorgerson’s extraordinary artwork illustrates. Now that’s ambitious. It is tempting to think how much better ‘The Wall’ would be as a single album, with the driftwood cut-out, and blame its weakness on the double album format, but I recently listened to ‘The Lamb Lies Down On Broadway’ – never one of my favourite Genesis albums – and it is quite brilliant, with all the linking passages between the better songs making perfect sense and contributing to the whole. ‘The Wall’ is just not that good. It’s nothing like as good as ‘Animals’, ‘Wish You Were Here’ and ‘Dark Side Of The Moon’, and there are days when I’d take Pink Floyd’s earlier work over any of those.
